file_content.text: We weathered this Empire's storm.
Without tethers of words, they wandered lost. Many were devoured by the Javelin's flames. We are bright today.
We learned much of this Empire, and to catch ourselves before leaping.
We drank this Empire's ebb and flow. We will know it again.
Is he utterly oblivious to the loss of our dear Nadia?
We're going after her as soon as we can.
Nadia isn't "lost."
Not only Nadia, but whatever information she found.
Don't forget the data.
Nadia can take care of herself. Our priority is defending Corellia.
I have to focus on the war.
That's rather chilly, wouldn't you say? We can't even be sure Nadia is still alive.
Words will not return Iresso who is lost. Only doing.
If we want Felix back, we can't stand here talking.
I agree.
And the tactical information he found could be crucial, too.
Don't forget the data.
Felix is one man, but the fate of the galaxy depends on us defending Corellia.
The war's more important.
Is duty to Iresso, as fellow hunter, to find. If he lives.
An escape pod did leave the Javelin before it blew, but we lost track when it entered Corellia's atmosphere.
We think the pod was caught in an automated landing system, for Coronet City's shipyards. So it's probably there. Somewhere.
To Corellia. To search, and to war.
Welcome, everyone. Supreme Chancellor, may I present our new allies.
I greet you, Gaden-Ko, and Hallow Voice. The Empire threatens our Core Worlds, and your strength will be vital in the days ahead.
The Core Worlds founded the Republic we defend. They are centers of government and commerce. Our society would crumble without them.
Now an Imperial fleet is en route to one of these besieged worlds, Corellia, carrying thousands of reinforcements. That fleet must never arrive.
We're ready to be of service, Supreme Chancellor.
We are at your command.
How many ships? Dozens?
How big is this fleet?
More than thirty troop carriers, but they aren't heavily armed. Our true problem is their escort.
Even now, the Republic must have enough teeth to handle it.
Can't you stop it?
The Imperial fleet is protected by a dreadnaught, the Javelin; without it, we could scatter them easily.
However, a functional dreadnaught would be a huge asset in defending the Core Worlds. I need you and your alliance to capture the Javelin.
You expect us to capture an entire dreadnaught?
That's a huge undertaking.
You excel at the impossible.
How, exactly?
It would be far less risky to simply put the Javelin out of action.
We could just destroy it.
We tried and failed. If the Javelin reaches Corellia's orbit under Imperial command, we are finished.
Your smaller force should help you to slip through their defenses, board the Javelin, and force the captain's surrender.
I must go. I leave this vital task in your capable hands. Good luck.
Jedi, you have a rational mind. You know trying to capture a dreadnaught with the forces we have is utter insanity.
If we remain true to our mission and to the Force, we cannot fail.
But the Force is with us.
Of course. I can't imagine how that slipped my mind.
If the opportunity arises, I'm fully prepared to cheat my way to victory.
Unless we fix the odds.
Ah. Excellent.
Do you see anyone else volunteering to do this?
We don't have a choice.
The curse of being exemplary--being needed. Very well.
To begin: Our ships distract the Javelin. You board.
They're expecting an attack. But a defensive formation, at a distance, would keep them distracted.
A careful approach would work.
That would keep our ships out of the fire, but capturing a dreadnaught isn't like boarding a raft.
A fleet that size needs coordination. Jamming the Javelin's signals would put them in disarray.
No. Cut their communications.
Might buy us enough time--taking a dreadnaught is a day's work.
These reinforcements could turn the tide. We must hit hard to get the Javelin's attention.
We'd need to attack.
They'll be up against state-of-the-art firepower. Unless we pull the plug.
We should go along--me, Tharan, Qyzen, everyone. We each take a few Voss commandos and our holocommunicator.
You head for the bridge, we split up and get the other sections under control.
This mission will need all of us to stand any chance of success.
Then we work as a team.
Glory shared is glory halved. But this is great prize.
The crew will have an entire ship's defenses to throw at us.
It won't be easy.
Rest assured, I have every intention of staying out of trouble.
I'll be relying on each of you to get this job done. Do not disappoint me.
I hope you can cope.
We'll manage. If you follow through.
Excellent. If you have this in hand, I should go. Corellia's defenders would benefit from my help.
May the Force be with you all.
Well, um, hello, Gaden-Ko.
I'm sorry, a Voss Mystic is rather new for us....
What he means is, on behalf of the Republic, we welcome you. And your very impressive entourage.
Thank you. I have three interpreters. Seven healers. Sixty commandos.
We must use the Voss healers sparingly, but they could save thousands of lives.
Those healers will be useful.
Voss commandos are crack infantry and scouts, and with those healers, they'll be unstoppable.
A small, but elite, army.
We fight the Sith. I will learn. My vision will guide.
That intuition of yours, and any visions you have, might win the war for us.
I need your visions more.
I will help. I do not control visions.
We will tread the stars beside you, one who sees.
What about this First Son, Jedi? Has anything new turned up?
Apparently, the First Son may be completely unaware of who he really is.
He may not know he's evil.
You mean... anyone could be the First Son? And not know it?
First Blaesus sat there spying on us, now we're not safe in our own heads!
We must be vigilant. Around the men, anyway.
The ambassador you sent me to meet was actually a Child of the Emperor.
Sophia Farash turned on me.
You're joking.
Sophia Farash? But I've known her since--I'll pass on the news.
A Child of the Emperor gave up some intelligence, but I think it's a lie.
Yes, but it's probably untrue.
You think those Children are trying to distract us?
Well, they know we're a threat. Still, I'd like to hear these "lies."
I'm sorry to interrupt. Master Syo's hosting a war council. He said you should join in right away.
We have convened to offer the condolences of the Jedi Order, on the passing of Senator Tobas Grell.
Nadia, your father was a great ally. We hope you'll continue his noble efforts to guide your people into the Republic.
I will. And everyone back home should respect me as his successor.
Remember, the first quality of a great leader is humility.
Beware of overconfidence.
You still have remarkable respect for your people's customs, despite your travels.
You've proven yourself.
I'll try, Master Satele. I don't think anyone will listen to me.
The Rift Alliance, the Jedi Council and myself are all here to help.
You have everyone's support.
Senator Grell's body is aboard, but he should be laid to rest.
Grell needs a burial.
We'll make all the arrangements to send him home.
Of course they won't, if you have that attitude.
Don't be defeatist.
There is another matter. Senator Grell's will was left in our care, and one portion concerns both of you.
...to the Institute of Xenozoology, if they can display it. But finally, my most important concern. My dear Nadia.
She is so gifted. But these "Children of the Emperor" are both gifted, and trained.
Therefore, I ask Nadia be accepted for a Padawan's training, and taught by the Barsen'thor of the Jedi Order.
We've had time to discuss it, and we consent for Nadia to become your Padawan.
An excellent idea. Nadia's strong in the Force, and quick to learn.
She'll be a good student.
Really? You'll train me?
This should be a joint decision.
Do you agree, Nadia?
Of course! I mean, thank you for the honor.
I have a right to choose my own Padawan.
What about my consent?
You don't want to help me?
Rare talents need a special master. Nadia must be trained, and you have experience of... unusual powers.
Nadia, a Padawan begins with a vow to honor her Master and the Jedi Code.
Oh. Then I, um, promise to follow the Jedi Code, and to respect my Master and listen to her lessons.
And I swear to teach you the ways of the Force, protect you from evil and remind myself that training is eternal.
I should also make a vow.
I believe you have a great future in our order.
A good beginning.
Your first lesson: Jedi prove themselves through actions, not words.
Be sure you do.
This is everything father wanted. He'd be so happy.
This proves what the blasted Empire's capable of. The Esh-kha won't be enough. We need more. Something... extraordinary.
Voss. If Jedi must pursue foolish hopes, try Voss. Whole planet of them.
Duin, every crazy spacer has a story about Voss and those "Mystics." You want to fight the Empire with legends?
I've never heard of this world, or the Mystics.
Voss? Mystics?
Don't dismiss him out of hand, maybe he's on to something.
I'm open to all ideas.
I'll take anyone willing to battle beside me, legend or not.
Whatever works.
Rumor says Voss is home to Force sensitives called "Mystics," who can heal any injury and see the future, counter any plan.
It's got to be exaggerated. But if there's any truth to it, these Mystics might swing a Republic victory.
Surely the Republic has investigated this planet beyond rumors.
That's all you know?
Sorry. The Voss people like their secrets.
Hopefully the Mystics are willing to discuss an alliance.
We should seek them out.
Untrained Force sensitives are dangerously unpredictable. These Mystics could join the enemy.
Or they could join the Empire.
Yes, the Council has seen that pattern before.
Come now, Syo, you don't need a Jedi to teach you right from wrong.
If you truly believe you must go to Voss, be wary. Those Mystics may use the Force, but they don't know our ways.
Good luck. Senator Grell's death should not be in vain.
Oh. Then I, er, promise to follow the Jedi Code, and to respect my Master and listen to his lessons.
Master Jedi? Captain Sulle, Belsavis Orbital security. We have a situation in progress. Senator Grell has been abducted.
Witnesses report Grell was leaving a meeting, when a heavily armed man took him prisoner.
Did this man hurt Senator Grell?
Was he wounded?
We don't know, but the kidnapper killed three guards who got between him and his ship.
Let me come and meet you.
I'm sorry, there's no point. The kidnapper's already gone.
I'll be there immediately to secure his release.
Then it's a hostage situation.
The kidnapper... already escaped, and no demands have been issued.
The systems in place to trap escaping vessels--the main tractor beam, our overrides--they've all been sabotaged. We're fixing them now.
But without them, we can't track the kidnapper's ship, and this is a week-long repair job at least.
Senator Grell may not have that time.
I'm sorry, we can't wait.
I have an exo-technology professor aboard. His help might cut that time down.
Tharan could speed it up.
Perhaps, but I wouldn't rely on a Republic tracking system. Captain, send any readings you gathered in the hangar.
This incompetence has put the life of a Republic Senator at risk.
Your security is a shambles.
Now now, there's more than one way to snare a gizka. Captain, send any readings you gathered from the hangar.
Ooh, let me look! Hmm. Oh, Tharan, his engine's using a tripartite ionization chamber.
What a rascal. A few atmospheric readings, Jedi, ten minutes to write an algorithm, and we'll plot the kidnapper's trail.
I knew I brought you along for a reason.
Excellent work, as always.
You flatter me, dear Jedi. Not without good reason, of course.
Besides, it'll be an excellent study for my next paper.
No time to waste, Tharan, Grell needs us.
Good. Get started.
Considering your upkeep, I expect nothing less.
So you have a use after all.
We'll endeavor not to disappoint.
I hope you find the Senator safe and sound. We'll double our security measures, Master Jedi; this won't happen again.
All right. When Tharan finds the kidnapper's ship, I--I'm going with you.
Leave this in my hands. I promise not to let you down.
I'd prefer you here, safe.
This is my father. I have to be there.
Prepare yourself and find a weapon, just in case. I'll call you when we arrive.
I understand. Go, get ready.
Right, I should... try and keep busy 'til then.
Rescue missions are very delicate. I can't have you underfoot.
You'll get in the way.
When father's away, I represent our homeworld and fleet. Either I go, or... or a third of those ships you need are going home.
Little Nadia's growing up.
I was only trying to keep you safe.
If you insist.
It seems my hands are tied.
You leave me no choice.
Fine. But in the future, remember--I don't like being threatened.
Don't try blackmail again.
I'm sorry. Please understand, I have to help him.
Father... please be alright.
Someone find Senator Grell. Whatever's keeping him, he has to see this.
I walk quietly. I am a newborn before you. All my steps were laid by Sky Hunter.
I walk quietly. I am a newborn before you. All my steps were laid by Ember Fist.
I walk quietly. I am a newborn before you. All my steps were laid by Silent Teeth.
Means the Jedi, I think. It's an Esh-kha?
Yes, Hallow Voice is an Esh-kha. He's also a person.
"He," not "it."
This is Hallow Voice, a patriarch of the Esh-kha.
Meet our new ally.
These are "diplomats," a... consequence of modern civilization.
Ignore them, Hallow Voice.
Wait, it's true? This is an Esh-kha? How many do we have?
We are an ocean, but every wave can speak. My brothers wait for your downstretched hand.
We'd better send a fleet to Belsavis for them right away. A big fleet. And weapons. Armor. Supplies....
Jedi, this... this is incredible. You got an army? Just the two of you?
Jedi, this is incredible. You got an entire army, single-handedly?
I had some assistance from an unexpected ally.
A Rakata helped me.
This isn't just an army. The Esh-kha are finally rejoining the galaxy.
And freed an entire people.
Of course, but... the Empire won't know what hit them!
In between fighting for my life against another Child of the Emperor.
No thanks to the Children.
You'd better tell us all about it.
Wait, everyone! There's a message--something's happened to father!
We put the monument's star coordinates through the navigation computer. That entire system is classified.
But, my Senate clearance got us some answers. It's a world called "Belsavis."
And the Esh-kha won't be lonely. The Republic's using Belsavis as a high-security prison.
I can still seek out the Esh-kha without causing a stir.
I'll be discreet.
I wonder if those prisoners realize there's an entire army under their feet.
They're in for a shock.
Without the Esh-kha, the Republic is finished. They'll have to grant me access.
I can't let that stop me.
That's not what worries me, Jedi; those things were locked up for a reason.
The Rakata didn't dare let a single Esh-kha go free. And you'll be releasing an entire army.
Maybe the Esh-kha who opposed this "galactic cleansing" can persuade the others.
Not all of them were killers.
If the Esh-kha rebel, they'll just go back in their box. But if they don't, the Republic gets powerful new shock troops.
I've balanced the risk.
All right. This seems awfully dangerous, but I believe in you.
My decision's made. Be quiet.
You're our leader, not our dictator. I have a right to express my concerns!
I'm sure she's considered all this carefully, Shuuru.
Of course, Shuuru, I'm sure he's considered them.
Careful, Jedi, the fate of the Republic depends on us staying united.
We should seek out these Esh-kha with all haste. I think they've been imprisoned long enough.
You can count on us, I promise.
